item.title: For the first time, a gay couple in Italy can adopt a baby
item.dc:creator: amerelliqz
item.content:encoded: The juvenile courtin Romeruled in favor of the adoption of a daughter by her mother's female partnerwhich makes the gay couple the first such pair to be granted an adoption in Italy. The judge said the couple met all the requirements the law demands from adoptive parents.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The couple had gone through artificial fertilization, and the mother and her partner have been raising the child together. While the judge essentially extendedlegal benefits to a de-facto situation, rather than granting an adoption at the outset of the parental bonding process, the rulingstill has been received by gay rights advocates as an important marker of progress.

item.title: TESTING CHART
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz

item.title: Burma misplaces nine million people
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: A recent census of thecountry also known as Myanmar revealeditspopulation to be 51 millionsignificantly less than the government's estimate of 60 million, which was based on the country'slast survey, in1983. The BBC reported that 800,000 members of the Muslim Rohingya minority were not allowed to identify themselves as such.

item.title: Stop ISIS nowor see terrorist attacks hit Europe and the US, says King Abdullah
item.dc:creator: gguilfordqz
item.content:encoded: Ifworld leaders don't fightISIS'reign of terrorin the Middle East, said the Saudi monarch, jihadist attacks "will reach Europe in a month and America in another month." On Aug. 29, US secretary of state John Kerry called for global military actionto halt ISIS' "genocidal agenda."

item.title: You're next, Saudi king warns the West
item.dc:creator: gguilfordqz
item.content:encoded: Jihadist attacks"will reach Europe in a month and America in another month" unlessworld leaders halt ISIL's reign of terror in the Middle East, said Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah.His words echo John Kerry's call for aglobal military effort to confrontISIL.

item.title: A Q2 recession makes Brazil's economic woes official
item.dc:creator: gguilfordqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/257793/the-weeks-14-most-important-economic-charts/

item.title: The average French worker's productivity is slowing
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/258151/reminder-dont-question-frances-35-hour-working-week/

item.title: Americans want their gunsand butter
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: And now there's a scarcity of the latter. Preference for a spread purer than margarine has bolstered US demand for butter. But the domesticmilk supply and its fat content are trailing expectations, leaving butter inventories at refrigerated warehouses 42% below last summer's levelsand pushing butter prices tonew highs.

item.title: No universal suffrage in Hong Kong
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz

item.title: Britain acts on homegrown jihadists
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The UK announced new anti-terror measures, including giving police thepower to seize passportsof citizens suspected of trying to travel to Syria and Iraq to join groups like the Islamic State (also known as ISIL or ISIS). Talks will be held on what to do with theseBritish citizenswhen they return to the UK, from prosecution to extra surveillance oreven, possibly, refusing them entry at the border.

item.title: Keep the laborers satisfied
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: A majority of Americans report that their co-workers are a bigger factor than salary when it comes to job satisfaction. This perhaps explains why, despite the depressing trends on national income, more than half the respondents in a CBS News poll said they are "very satisfied" with their jobs.

item.title: A new iPayments system?
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: Maybe Apple and American Express can do what Google hasn't done yet andbring about the broad embrace ofthe concept of the mobile wallet. Re/Code reports that AmEx is involved in a payments product that will be unveiledSept. 9, when the iPhone 6 is expected to debut.

item.title: Putin's provocative speech
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Russian president Vladimir Putin called for talks onstatehood for the eastern part of Ukraine (he wants more autonomy for the region, but not independence from Ukraine), and said Ukrainian officials should negotiate directly with pro-Russian rebels. The conflict is pulling in fighters from around Europe for both sides, the BBC reports.

item.title: A slight delay for Alibaba's IPO
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Alibaba Group Holding is pushing back investor meetings about its initial public offering for "about a week" to answer additional questions from the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bloomberg reports. The IPO, which is expected to raise more than $20 billion for Alibaba, may price on Sept. 18 and start trading on the 19th, several days later than was reported two weeks ago.

item.title: Hong Kong's pro-democracy activists clash with police
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Hong Kong protestors were pepper sprayed by police at anews conference to explain Beijing's rejection of universal suffrage for the city's citizens. Lastnight, an activist told a crowd of thousands that this decisionwould mark an"era of civil disobedience."

item.title: China's insurers get creative
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: To drum up business in a stagnant market, Chinese insurance companies are taking to increasingly outlandish promotions. Add-ons to policies include covering cancelled honeymoons due to accidental pregnancies, refunding thecost of treatingburns from simmering stew "hot pot" meals, and paying for damage caused by"mischievous and destructive" toddlers.

item.title: America's dairy industry can't keep up with butter demand
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/257982/americans-are-about-to-be-reminded-that-butter-is-a-luxury/

item.title: A big fund manager fears spiralling bank fines.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Neil Woodford, a British fund manager, sold his firm's stake in HSBC on fears of "fine inflation." Despite apparent bargainsinbig-bankshares, thegrowingfines for bad behavior representtoo great arisk,he explained.Woodford is an influential figure; others may follow his lead.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This is the key passage from the fund manager'scomments about selling out of HSBC:
I am concerned, however, that these fines are increasingly being sized on a banks ability to pay, rather than on the extent of the transgression. In particular, I am worried that the ongoing investigation into the historic manipulation of Libor and foreign exchange markets could expose HSBC to significant financial penalties. Not only are these potentially serious offences in the eyes of the regulator, but HSBC is very able to pay a substantial fine. The size of any potential fine is unquantifiable, so this represents an unquantifiable risk.

item.title: Russia flexes its muscles, looks east
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Russia's foreign minister called for an "immediate ceasefire" in Ukraine ahead of a meeting with his Ukrainian counterpart in Minsk. Earlier, president Vladimir Putin said statehood should be discussedfor the breakaway regions of eastern Ukraine. China, meanwhile, appears to be siding with Russiaofficials from Beijing are in Siberia to break ground on a pipeline that will carry gas to China.

item.title: Barclays dumps its Spanish unit at a loss
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The costly clean-up of Barclays continues, with the British bank offloading mostof its operations in Spain to local lender CaixaBank. Theurgency of the bank's "bold simplification" plan is apparent in the movethe Spanish operations were priced at only half of their book value,saddling Barclays with a loss of 500 million ($831 million).

item.title: China gets tough on Microsoft
item.dc:creator: lmiraniqz
item.content:encoded: Chinese antitrust regulators have given Microsoft a 20-day deadline to explainthe relationship between the firm's Windows operating system and its Office suite of products. Thanks to rampant softwarepiracy China is already a tough market for Microsoftitmakes less money there than in the Netherlands.

item.title: Western countriesdig in against Russia.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The EU is proposingnew, tougher sanctionson Russian companies, and is even considering boycotting the 2018 World Cup (paywall). Barack Obamais headedtoEstoniato give US allies a pep talk, and NATO is planning a military exercise in Ukraine this month with more than 1,000 troops.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: On Monday, officials fromthe self-proclaimed"People's Republics" of Donetsk and Luhansk met with representatives fromUkraine and Russia, airing demands for special recognitionthat fall short of full independence, but not by much.Kyiv's forces lost control of Luhansk's airport, reportedly to a column of tanks. Some 700 government troops have been takenprisoner by separatistsduringthe latest surge of violence. Ukraine's defense minister said a "full-scale invasion" was underway, and provocatively warned that Russia could deploy tactical nukes.

item.title: US strikes target al-Shabab leader in Somalia.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: The Pentagon confirmed reports of drone strikes near the port city of Barawe, part of a counter-terrorism operation apparently aimed at the group's leader, Ahmed Abdi Godane. He is thought to be the mastermind behind the 2013 attack on the Westgate mall in Nairobi, which killed 67.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The strikes on the group's meeting place comes one day after the Islamist group set off a car bomb and fired their way into a prison in Mogadishu. Three security guards and two civilians were killed, while 15 others were injured.

item.title: Eric Cantor moves to Wall Street.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: The former US house majority leader is joining boutique investment bank Moelis & Co. as vice chairman, he told The Wall Street Journal (paywall). Cantor, a Republican representative from Virginia, lost his seat in the House of Representatives to economics professor Dave Brat in June.

item.title: England's top soccer clubs have spent a record amount of money on players this year
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/258778/epl-clubs-are-spending-like-crazy-and-fans-will-end-up-footing-the-bill/

item.title: The rise of wholesome.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Young British women are binge drinking far less than they did just a decade ago, teenage smoking is plummeting and the number of young people that have tried cannabis has dropped by a third, the Telegraphreports. Reports of incredibly promiscuous behavior among US teens have been wildly exaggerated by the media, a new book finds.

item.title: US fast food workers plan to strike
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Employees at McDonald's, Burger King and other fast-food chains across the US plan to strike on Sept. 4, demanding a $15/hour wage, organizers announced. Workers in over 100 US cities plan to use "non-violent civil disobedience" to call attention to their demands, The New York Times reported (paywall).

item.title: Deutschland ber Uber.
item.dc:creator: lmiraniqz
item.content:encoded: A court in Germany has banned Uber, a taxi-sharing app, from operating in the country, ruling that it did not havethe necessary permits. The judgement is a temporary one, and could be overturned; the companyhad some successfighting previous bans in Berlin and Hamburg.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
What is the reasoning behind Germany'sUber ban? Quartz's Tim Fernholz reports:

In this case, Reuters reports that the court made the decision not out of concern for the safety of passengers, but because German law says that people without commercial drivers licenses can only charge for the operating costs of giving other people rides, not attempt to make a profit.

If that seems like a way to restrict competition, it probably is: Uber says it already performs background checks on its German drivers and provides blanket insurance for anyone using its platform to provide car services.

item.title: Archer Daniels Midland sells its global chocolate business to Cargill.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The two sides have agreed to a price of $440 million. The sale is expected to take place in the first half of 2015, subject to regulatory approval, and will help expand Cargill's chocolate growth in North America and Europe.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Both companies press releases outline the specifics included in the sale. ADM is selling its chocolate manufacturing operations in Hazleton, Pennsylvania; Milwaukee, Wisconsin; Georgetown, Ontario; Liverpool, U.K.; Manage, Belgium; and Mannheim, Germany. Cargill will also get around 700 employees with the sale.

item.title: Dollar General is desperate for Family Dollar.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The top US discount retailer raised its bid for Family Dollar to $9.1 billion, after its $8.95 billion offer was rejected last month. Dollar Generalalso offered to pay a $500 million penaltyif antitrust regulators block the deal, butwarned it could make a hostile bid if this one is rejected. Family Dollarsaid that for now it's sticking to an $8.5 billion offer from Dollar Tree.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Venessa Wong in Bloomberg Businessweek recently explained what's at stake in the three-way takeover battle:
At issue is who will dominate lower-income and small-town discount retailing in the U.S. now that Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) has moved more upscale. Its one of the best opportunities in retail, says Edward Jones analyst Brian Yarbrough. There are a lot of small, rural markets that cant support a giant Target (TGT) or Wal-Mart, whose largest stores can exceed 170,000 square feet, but can support a 7,500-square-foot dollar store.

item.title: Boko Haram extends its caliphate.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Nigeria'sIslamist insurgentshave reportedlyseizedthe northeastern town of Bama, killing "scores" of residentsand drivingout thousands. Last month Boko Haram captured another town,Gwoza, and declared it part of the Islamic caliphate.The capture of Bama,if confirmed,bringsthe group closer tothe regionalcapital, Maiduguri.

item.title: Halliburton settles over the 2010 BP oil spill.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The companyhas agreed to pay $1.1 billion to settlemostof the lawsuits over its role inthe largest offshore oil spill in US history. The deal, subject to court approval, will sit ina trust untilappeals are resolved. Halliburton wasblamedfordefective cement work on the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Transocean, which owned the rig, has has settled claims for $1.4 billion. BP has paid more than $28 billion and could be due formore. The Environmental Law Institute has a database of claims related to the disaster, and an overview (pdf) of who's liable for what.

item.title: Radioactive boars are on the loose in Germany.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Bad news for sausage lovers: More than a third of wild boarsin Saxony have unacceptable levels of cesium-137. Scientistsbelieve the root of the problem is radioactive contaminationfrom theChernobyl nuclear accident, which has blownwestwards as far as France, and accumulatedin mushrooms and truffles that the boars like to eat.

item.title: Home Depot is investigating a possible credit-card breach.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The UShome-improvements store is looking into signs thathackers may have stolen a large batch of credit- and debit-card data, according to security journalistBrianKrebs. The case appearssimilar tobut possibly even bigger thanthe massive security breach that the retailer Target suffered last year (and from which it is still recovering).

item.title: Islamic State beheads another journalist.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Steven Sotloff, anAmericanreporter captured last yearinSyria, has been executed, according to the research firm Site Intelligence Group,whichhas circulateda video(this is not a link to it) apparently showing his beheading. The jihadist groupkilled journalist James Foley in a similar manner last month. The video, which was confirmed as authentic by the US,alsothreatens British captive David Haineswith the same fate.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sotloff was a freelancer dedicated to covering the aftermath of the Arab Spring. He was kidnapped shortly after journeying to Syria for the second time in 2013, according to Reuters, and told colleagues he understood the dangers of covering the country's civil war. He worked for a number of titles including World Affairs, Time magazine, and Foreign Policy.

item.title: Ebola is "out of control."
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The director ofthe US Centers forDisease Control saidtheEbola epidemicis "going to get worse in the very near future." In Liberia,healthcare workers have gone on strike over unpaid wages, and there are food shortages ininfected regions, according to the UN. All eyes are on GlaxoSmithKline'sexperimental vaccine, which begins human trialsthis week.

item.title: The Irish still aren't paying off their mortgages
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/258786/in-ireland-you-still-dont-have-to-pay-your-mortgage/

item.title: The annual rise of healthcare prices in the US is slowing.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/259066/americas-great-healthcare-hyperinflation-is-over/

item.title: LinkedIn may have gone too far with its China censorship.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Users have complained that when Chinese users share posts that are deemed to be in violation of Beijing's rules, the company blocks the contentnot only in China, but in all of the countries where it operates.We do want to get this right, and we are strongly considering changing our policy so that content from our Chinese members that is not allowed in China will still be viewed globally, a LinkedIn spokesman told Bloomberg.

item.title: LinkedIn may have gone too far with its China censorship.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Users have complained that posts from Chinese users that are objectionable to Beijing are blocked around the world. We do want to get this right, and we are strongly considering changing our policy so that content from our Chinese members that is not allowed in China will still be viewed globally, a LinkedIn spokesman told Bloomberg.

item.title: Shinzo Abe reshuffles his cabinet.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Japans prime minister appointed five womenas ministers, along with two pro-China politicians. Despite the shake-up, don't expect any major changes to Abenomics: His key economic ministers and chief cabinet secretary arent going anywhere.

item.title: A ceasefire in eastern Ukraine?
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: After someconfusing back-and-forth(paywall), it seems the Ukrainian and Russian presidents have indeed agreed to the outlines of a peace plan, though Russia saysitcannot signa formal ceasefire because itis "not a party" to the conflict in Ukraine. (Yeah, right, saidBarack Obama.) Either way, themarkets are happy, with sharp gains in Russian shares and the ruble.

item.title: Netflix goes global with "Gotham."
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The videocompany has obtained exclusive global rights to stream the Warners Bros. Batman prequel seriesas it expands into five European countries this month, including France and Germany(paywall).

item.title: Netflix goes global with "Gotham."
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The video company has obtained exclusive global rights to stream the Warner Bros. Batman prequel seriesas it expands into five European countries this month, including France and Germany(paywall).

item.title: French luxury giants declare a truce.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton will give up its $7.5 billion stake in Hermes, which it acquired stealthily through the purchase of derivatives from several banks, after a French court intervened to end a four-year legal battle between the companies. The 23% holding will be distributed to LVMH's shareholders.

item.title: How do you "degrade and destroy" the Islamic State?
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: With even moderate Democratstheir eyes on the November congressional electionnow challengingthe Obama administrationto do something about the jihadist group,the president and his policy chiefs are all talking tough. But "degrading and destroying" IS wouldbe a long haul.Below are some analyses we'vefound useful.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
• Mark Gollum at CBCprovides a good overview of what fighting IS in Iraq and Syria will entail."Degrading is relatively easy. It's the destruction part thats very difficult."
  • Kenneth Pollack at the Brookings Institutionargues it's possible to"turn Syria's opposition into a real fighting force."
  • Anthony Cordesman at CSISelaborates on the many moving parts an anti-IS strategy would have to have. "Any effort to defeat the Islamic state must be far more than a military or a tactical struggle. It is a political and ideological struggle as well, and the United States must mobilize itself and its allies to use every possible tool."

item.title: CVS quits smoking.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Effective today, all of CVS's 7,700 stores are tobacco-free,a month earlier than planned. The US drugstore chain is sacrificing $1.5 billion in annual tobacco sales as part of a mission to become a healthcare-oriented destination, and has changed its corporate name from CVS Caremark toCVS Health.

item.title: The world needs more Ebola drugs.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The British nurse infected with Ebola has made a full recovery after being administered ZMapp, the experimental drug, buta third American missionary worker has been infected(paywall)in Liberia and the virus has made an appearance in a new region in Guinea. The World Health Organization has called for an Ebola drug summit, while GlaxoKlineSmith's vaccine begins human trials this week.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Dr. Kent Bradley, the American doctor who survived the virus, recounts his experiences while infected. "I felt like I was about to die," Bradley told NBC News in an exclusive.

item.title: Samsung unveils its new designs.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Samsung, still the world's top smartphone maker, unveiled its latest Galaxy Note device today in Berlin. Samsunglong accused of copying rival Apple's designsalso showed off something truly unique: A strange new gadget with a bizarre curved screen. Don't expect one of those on the new iPhones, which Apple is expected to announce next week.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Here's what Samsung's new curved gadget looks like: [caption id="attachment_259569" align="alignnone" width="320"] The Verge[/caption]

item.title: Could the NATO summit be cyber-attacked?
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: While president Obama is in Estonia assuringBaltic leaders that NATO allies will defend them from any Russian aggression, British police are beefing up cyber-security(paywall) for Thursday's NATO summit in Wales, afterintelligence services were put on"high alert" for an electronic attack.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: An action plan in response to the Ukraine crisis is likely to emerge from the two-day summit, especially involving the organization'snew members in the east: Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Poland.

item.title: Big US banks will need to fatten their cash cushions.
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: US regulators adoptednew rulesrequiringlarge banks to keepenough cashor liquid assets, like government bonds, that can be quickly turned into cashto survive a funding squeeze. The "liquidity coverage ratio" won't befully phased in until early 2017. As always, the devil lies in the details, specifically what kinds of investmentswill officially count asliquid enough.

item.title: Microsoft's Cortana is taking a crack at the NFL.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: After Microsoft's digital assistant had a near-perfect streak in predicting the winners of World Cupmatches this summer,Bing is taking its talents to a new level. The prediction technology is going to be applied to American football, a day before the season kicks off.

item.title: Phablets are the future.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The oversized smartphones that tech journalists couldn't stop laughing about when they were first invented are now laughing back. Research firm IDC predicts worldwide phablet shipments will overtake laptops this year and tablets next year.

item.title: Phablet sales are on the rise.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/259689/why-apple-is-finally-making-a-huge-iphone-6/

item.title: France finally stood up to Russia.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The French government suspended its1.1 billion ($1.5 billion) deal to sell two warships to Russia,in the face of growing pressure from its allies. That'll be painful to French industry, but could win Francea reprievefrom Germanyscoldingit forfiscal imprudence.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: After someconfusing back-and-forth(paywall), the Ukrainian and Russian presidents seemed to agree earlier on Wednesdayto the outlines of a peace plan, though Russia saysitcannot signa formal ceasefire because itis "not a party" to the conflict in Ukraine. (Yeah, right, saidBarack Obama.) Either way, themarkets were happy, with sharp gains in Russian shares and the ruble. The to-and-fro threatened to gum up a European Union meeting on tougher sanctions against Russia today. Some member countries such as Italy and Slovakia are deeply ambivalent about new sanctions, while Estonia and Lithuania are suggesting the biggest punishment of allsuspension of Russia's hosting of the 2018 World Cup.

item.title: Michael Bloomberg is back in business.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The former New York City mayor will once again leadhis eponymous media and financial information company, despite his earlier claims that he wouldfocus on giving away his $32.8 billion fortune. Daniel Doctoroff, Bloomberg's longtime friend and lieutenant, will step aside as Bloomberg LP's CEO.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Doctoroff told the New York Times: "Mike is kind of like God at the company. He created the universe. He issued the Ten Commandments and then he disappeared. And then he came back. You have to understand that when God comes back, things are going to be different. When God reappeared, people defer.

item.title: Bernie Madoff's last surviving son dies.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Andrew Madoff, the convicted Ponzi schemer's 48-year-old son, had mantle cell lymphoma; his brother Mark committed suicide in 2010. One way to think of this, Andrew Madoffonce said in an interview, is the scandal and everything that happened killed my brother very quickly, and its killing me slowly.

item.title: China and India are skipping the UN's climate change summit.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The absence of the leaders of the world's largestand third-largestcarbon emitters, respectively, will undercut attempts to reach an agreementoncutting greenhouse gases and combating global warming.

item.title: Putin set terms fora Ukraine ceasefire.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Russian president laid out a plan to end the fighting between Kyiv and pro-Russian forces in eastern Ukraine. Earlier, Russia said itcouldn't signa formal ceasefire because itis not a party to the conflict in Ukraine. (Yeah, right, said US president Barack Obama.)

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Putin's planannounced on the eve of a critical NATO summitwould require Kyiv's forces to withdraw from the pro-Russian rebel-held territories of Luhansk and Donestk, creating a de facto rebel state(paywall), much like the pro-Russian zones ofAbkhazia and South Ossetia in Georgia, and Transnistria in Moldova.

item.title: NATO talks tough on Russia.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Both the NATO head, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, and US president Barack Obamahave challenged Russia's claims that it's not involved in the separatist uprising in eastern Ukraine; NATO says Russiahas over 1,000troops there. NATO leaders are in Wales today and tomorrow to work out a strategyonRussia and the Middle East; problems in Afghanistan are getting sidelined.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Russian president Vladimir Putin's planfor a ceasefireclearly timed to pre-empttheNATO summitwould require Kyivs forces to withdraw fromLuhansk and Donetsk, the separatist-held territories,creating a de facto rebel state(paywall)much like the pro-Russian zones ofAbkhazia and South Ossetia in Georgia, and Transnistria in Moldova. In short, creating another frozen conflicttokeep Ukraine off-balance for the long term.

item.title: Mario Draghi sticks his neck out.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The European Central Bank presidentcut the euro zone's benchmark interest rate to a new all-time low, 0.05%, from 0.15%, and said the ECB will startquantitative easing next month. The markets were pleased;Draghi's promise to "do whatever it takes" to prop up the euro will soon be put to the test.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_260116" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Ebola spreads to southern Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: There are three cases and 6o people "at high risk" in Port Harcourt. Across West Africa, theWorld Health Organizationsays, the rate of new infections is accelerating. Johnson and Johnson is speeding up work(paywall) on a vaccine, but human trials won'tbe possible until next year.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Budget cuts at the WHO have weakened its ability to react to the Ebola epidemic, writes Sheri Fink at the New York Times(paywall):
The W.H.O. simply did not have the staffing or ability to flood the Ebola zone with help, said [its director-general,] Dr. [Margaret] Chan... It was a fantasy, she argued, to think of the W.H.O. as a first responder ready to lead the fight against deadly outbreaks around the world...Its outbreak and emergency response units have been slashed, veterans who led previous fights against Ebola and other diseases have left, and scores of positions have been eliminated precisely the kind of people and efforts that might have helped blunt the outbreak in West Africa before it ballooned into the worst Ebola epidemic ever recorded.

item.title: The French are stocking up on presidential gossip.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Merci Pour Ce Moment(Thanks For This Moment), the kiss-and-tell memoir by Valrie Trierweiler, the ex-partner of French president Franois Hollande, was published today, and it's already the top selleron Amazon (link in French). She writes that she attempted suicideafterHollande dumped her, and that he pejorativelycalls poorpeople"les sans-dents" (the toothless).

item.title: Lego is now the world's biggest toymaker
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/259994/lego-is-now-the-worlds-largest-toymaker-as-kids-choose-bricks-over-barbie/

item.title: The US Justice Department probes Ferguson's police.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Attorney-general Eric Holder will announce an investigationtoday intolast month'sfatalshooting of unarmed black teenager Michael Brown and the subsequent riots. That could lead to either a lawsuit against the police or a "consent decree" mandating reforms; over20 US cities have adopted such decrees sincethe police beating thattriggered the 1994Los Angeles riots.

item.title: Americans are changing the world olive-oil industry
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/256888/the-coming-rise-of-pure-premium-american-olive-oil/

item.title: BP is mostly to blame for the 2010 Gulf oil spill.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: A US judge has foundBP grosslynegligent in thelargest offshore oil spill in US history. BP has paid more than $28 billion in fines(paywall) and couldnow pay billions more. The energy company,which saw its shares drop 5% after the ruling, said it will appeal the decision.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The judgeapportioned 67% of the blame to BP, 30% to Transoceanwhich owned the Deepwater Horizon drilling rigand 3% to Halliburton, which yesterdaysettled for $1.1 billionover claims of defective cement work.

item.title: Nevada scores a Tesla factory.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The electric-car producer chose an industrial park outsideRenofor its "gigafactory," which aims tomakeenough batteries to power a half-million new vehicles a year by 2020. Nevada wasvying with California, Texas, Arizona, and New Mexico to house the plant, which is projected to employ 6,500 workers by 2020.

item.title: Ukraine dominates the NATO summit.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: French president Franois Hollande, along with British government sources, said the EU could impose further economic sanctions on Russia tomorrow. Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenko and the main separatist leader said they would both order ceasefires at tomorrow's Minsk meeting.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The plans come a day after Russian president Vladimir Putin announced hisplanfor a ceasefirethat would require Kyivs forces to withdraw fromLuhansk and Donetsk, the separatist-held territories,creating a de facto rebel state(paywall).

item.title: New York Fashion Week starts.
item.dc:creator: javinsqz
item.content:encoded: Designers will show their Spring 2015 collectionsduring eight days of runway shows, presentations, and parties. The eventwhich kicks off the season of shows to follow in London, Paris, and Milanis expected to bring some $435million to New YorkCityin hotel stays, venue leasing (It costs $60,000 to rent a tent at Lincoln Center), retail sales, and more.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Earlier today,Coach's relatively new creative director Stuart Vevers showed the brand's second ever womenswearcollection. Fashion editors seemed to like the designer's youthfulfuzzy coats and punchy pastelsgood news for Coach, which could use a turnaround.

item.title: Alibaba's IPO will dwarf all the others
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/259565/it-has-been-a-huge-year-for-us-ipos-and-its-just-warming-up/

item.title: US fast-food workers demonstrate.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Workers at burger chains protested in 150 US cities to demand a $15-an-hour minimum wage and other benefits. Many jobs pay only just over the $7.25 federal minimum. Organizers said it was shaping up to bethe biggest actionso far in a two-year campaign.

item.title: The EU tightens the screws on Russia.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: EU ambassadors are expected to approve(paywall) new sanctions against Russias biggest energy firms, while NATO leadersfinalize their strategyin Wales. Ukrainian prime minister Petro Poroshenko and the top rebel leader Alexander Zakharchenko are also preparedto order a ceasefire, provided an agreement gets signed.

item.title: If the US National Football League were a media company...
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/260053/how-the-nfl-could-destroy-traditional-tv-if-it-wanted-to/

item.title: The Obamacare website was hacked.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Hackers broke into a Healthcare.gov computer server and uploaded malicious files that could be used to launch attacks against other websites. The intrusion, which took place in July, was disclosed for the first time on Thursday in a briefing to US legislators, who were told that the server did not contain any personal data.

item.title: The EU and NATO tighten the screws on Russia.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: EU ambassadors are expected to approve(paywall) new sanctions against Russias biggest energy firms, while NATO leadersfinalize their strategyin Wales. Ukrainian prime minister Petro Poroshenko and the top rebel leader Alexander Zakharchenko are also preparedto order a ceasefire, provided an agreement gets signed.

item.title: Apple comes under more scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Ahead of a big expected iPhone and iWatch launch next week, two US labor groups have accused a Chinese supplier of Apple of labor violations, including excessive hours and not using adequate protective gear.Separately, CEO Tim Cook promised new security measures for iCloud users after naked celebrity photos were posted online.

item.title: Boko Haram is poised to strike again.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Hundreds are fleeing Nigeria's Borno state, fearing the Islamic militant groups imminent takeover. Officials warn the group could advance on Maiduguri, the state capital, following its gain of control in the city of Bama. This would be a big, strategic win for Boko Haram in anever-worsening Nigerian security situation.

item.title: Few signs of peacemaking in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Ukrainianforces began shellingpro-Russian rebels near the strategic port of Mariupol, ahead of a planned meeting between Kiev and rebel leadership to agree on a ceasefire and possible peace plan. Meanwhile, the Russian central bank saidit was ready to take "non-standard measures" to mitigate the impact ofwesternssanctions, but declined to specify what that meant.

item.title: European markets digest Draghi's drastic moves.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: After yesterday'sunexpectedly aggressive moves by ECB president Mario Draghi, the euro remains near a 14-month low against the dollar, suggesting that markets believe the ECB's$1 trillion in bond-buyingwill kickstart growth. A forward-looking gauge of inflationalso hit a two-year high, a sign that fears of deflation mightfinally be receding.

item.title: The US economy limps along.
item.dc:creator: zachseward
item.content:encoded: Only 142,000 new jobs were created in August, falling short of expectations. The unemployment rate fell to 6.1%. Participation in the labor market remainsat levelsnot seen since the late 1970s, and wage growth is still non-existent. Other key charts and data arehere.

item.title: Hotels are following airlines in gouging you with fees.
item.dc:creator: zachseward

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/260087/hotels-are-following-airlines-lead-in-gouging-you-with-fees/

item.title: A ceasefire in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenkohas ordered Ukrainian forces to cease fire at 6pm local time (11am US Eastern time, 3pm GMT), after signing a ceasefire dealwith separatist rebels. NATO says Russia, however, has"escalated" the conflict(paywall) and is still sending in more troops. NATO is creatinga 4,000-strong "rapid reaction force" to protect the Baltic countries.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
For further reading:
  • The Guardian is live-blogging the NATO summit in Wales.
  • TheAP is regularly updating its story on the fighting in Ukraine.
  • Vox has a 24-page complete guide to the Ukraine crisis.

item.title: A "core coalition" against the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Ten countries areforming a US-led "core coalition"that will support Iraqi and Kurdish forces against the Islamic State but not send in any troops of their own.The other nineare Britain, France, Germany, Canada, Australia, Turkey, Italy, Poland, and Denmark. The group has two weeks towork out its plans.

item.title: Will Dollar General take it out with Family Dollar's shareholders?
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Family Dollar rejected Dollar General's takeover bid of $9.1 billion, citing its antitrust concerns. Dollar Generalraised its bid for Family Dollar after its $8.95 billion offer was rejected and offered to pay a $500 million penaltyif antitrust regulators block the deal. They also warned that if the revised bid was rejected, they would take the offer directly to Family Dollar's shareholders.

item.title: Starbucks moves both up- and downmarket.
item.dc:creator: mnisenqz
item.content:encoded: The coffee chainannounced plansto open 100 premium "Starbucks Reserve" cafesand to pilot limited-menu "Express" stores in New York City, in response to competition from high-end roasters for coffee snobs and from fast-food rivals for commuters. The first stores of both types are expected to opennext year.

item.title: NASA says an asteroid will fly "very close" to Earth this weekend.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Fear notthe newly discovered celestial body, expected to fly over New Zealand on Sunday, won't hit the planet. It won't even be visible to the naked eye. But the space rock, about 60 feet (18 meters) long, will be near enough to give scientists an opportunity to study it.

item.title: US airstrikes kill al-Shabab's leader.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The Pentagon has confirmed that Somali militant leader Ahmed Abdi Godanewas killedthis week in US drone strikes targeting al-Shabab's meeting place. Godaneis thought to be the mastermind behind the 2013 attack on the Westgate mall in Nairobi, which killed 67 people.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Godane isresponsible for bringing the Islamist militant groupto power. Voice of America writes:
The director of the Heritage Institute for Policy Studies in Mogadishu, Abdi Aynte, told VOA's Somali service that Godane has ruled al-Shabab with an iron fist and sought to model the group's global jihadist identity after himself. He was running the organization by himself and was essentially branding the organization as his own, said Aynte.

item.title: Belief in ghosts is very widespread.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: So much so that some scholars think Western society's embrace of the paranormal is experiencing a revival. Some 42% of Americans say they believe in ghosts; in the U.K., 52% are believers, according to the Atlantic. Reports of paranormal experiences also are fairly commonplace, but sleep paralysis may explain some of the purported encounters.

item.title: Alibaba is valued at $155 billion.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Earlier today, the Wall Street Journal reported that Alibaba willletemployees and close acquaintances buy shares at the public offering price in advance(paywall) of the stock's US debut. Such "friends and family" programs, popular in the dot.com boom, are regaining momentum; China's Weibo and JD.com each used one recently.

item.title: A business jet has crashed in Jamaica.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The small plane,believed to be owned by a real estate developer from Rochester, NY, was flying unresponsive over the Atlantic Ocean, the Associated Press reported. The US Air Force senttwo F-15 jets to shadowthe plane, in which the pilot appeared to be slumped unconscious over the controls. NBC reports that the jet's ownerand his wife were onboard the plane and were killed in the crash.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://twitter.com/LaurenPetracca/status/507989558882234368

Model airplane with Larry and Jane Glazer's name on it in an office window at Buckingham Properties @DandC pic.twitter.com/wSC52smaxj

— Lauren Petracca (@LaurenPetracca) September 5, 2014

item.title: Iraq captures a Chinese terrorist fighting for the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: TheDefense Ministry posted pictures on its Facebook page of a Chinese manwhom it says was fighting on behalf of the Islamic State. A Chinese official said in July that 100 of his countrymen arefighting in the Middle East.

item.title: Greece's economy is growing again.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The nation, the subject oftwo huge bailouts from the European Union and the IMF, will show its first quarterly expansion since 2008 in the third quarter, the finance minister said. The Greek economy is expected to grow 0.6% this yeara triumph after years of painful austerity.

item.title: Sierra Leone is imposing a four-day Ebola curfew.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Citizens must remain confined to their homes in a nationwide Sept 18-21 "lockdown." The goal is to "deal with the spread of Ebola once and for all." Nearly 500 of the 2,100 killed by the disease so far this year were in Sierra Leone.
